jiggle bones support
data.body:
Jiggle bones are bones that are animated procedurally in realtime with a physics engine. Used for clothing, items a moving character/ object, hair, hats, bunny ears, etc.

Also, ragdolls. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wKLaMN9dnjQ

Reference:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RmCNxNkrrKQ
https://wiki.teamfortress.com/wiki/Jiggle_bones

data.title: H5 canvas polygon fix
data.body:
Fix for canvas_draw_polygon so it works in H5 export.

1) Created one buffer for indices for using with drawElements.
2) Increased the vertex buffer size to 4096 if we are on WebGL build.

data.title: The play window opens always over the editor
data.body:
Usually, when debugging, i move the playing window apart so i can see the code and at the same time the play window.
When I start another debugging session, the play windows appears again over the code window. It would be nice it remembered where it was placed the last time and open the window directly there.

data.title: Screen capture upside down
data.body:
The PNG file saved with the following code is saved upside down (vertically flipped). Also the alpha in shadows appears to be saved incorrectly.

``` GDScript
var capture = get_viewport().get_screen_capture()
if !capture.empty():
    capture.save_png("screenshot.png")
```

Here's how the scene looks on my screen while the game is running. This is correct:

![Actual game screen](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/7063628/godot-screencap/screenshot-actual.png)

Here's an example image using the code above. The lowest layer in the scene is the water and ground which are 100% opaque. The alpha from the shadows in this screenshot are not blending correctly with the lower layers in the scene. You can see the transparency problem better if you download the PNG and view it in an image editing program.

![Sample RGBA PNG](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/7063628/godot-screencap/screenshot-rgba.png)

I can fix the alpha so that it is correctly blended by changing the code but it is still flipped:

`capture.converted(Image.FORMAT_RGB).save_png("screenshot.png")`

![Sample RGB PNG](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/7063628/godot-screencap/screenshot-rgb.png)

data.title: add OptionButton bind "set_item"
data.body:
Set an item in OptionButton by idx.  Either emit signal or not.  Useful for setting a
default item without signalling the emit call.

data.title: Add static and dynamic batching support?
data.body:
I believe the performance of Godot can benefit from minimizing drawcalls via  static and dynamic batching support.

Here's what I found out from the [5000 sprites benchmark](https://github.com/marynate/godot.benchmark) :
- Testing 5000 sprites on screen without dynamic batching:

> Unity 5: 50001 drawcalls, 173 fps
> Godot: 50001 drawcalls, 175 fps

By turning off dynamic batching feature, Unity 5 and Godot has almost identical fps.
- Testing 5000 sprites on screen with dynamic batching:

> Unity 5: 2 drawcalls, 278 fps
> Godot: n/a
> Urho3D; ? drawcalls: 785 fps

WIth Dynamic batching, the drawcalls could be dramatically reduced hence the improvement of fps on Unity 5.

**Reference**:
[Dynamic and Static Batching in Unity](http://docs.unity3d.com/Manual/DrawCallBatching.html)
[OpenGL Batch Rendering](http://www.gamedev.net/page/reference/index.html/_/technical/opengl/opengl-batch-rendering-r3900)
[Sprite Batching in OpenGL ES 2.0](http://antonholmquist.com/blog/sprite-batching-opengl-es-2-0/)
[SpriteBatch in libgdx](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/graphics/g2d/SpriteBatch.java)
[CCSpriteBatchNode in cocos2d-x](https://github.com/cocos2d/cocos2d-x/blob/8716164a5d95480b7d61d114c215b4c4cb762077/cocos/2d/CCSpriteBatchNode.cpp)
[Batch in Urho3D](https://github.com/urho3d/Urho3D/blob/90833996fa797d6ecbac27ed78123b85fb974b42/Source/Urho3D/Graphics/Batch.cpp)

data.title: H5build Fix
data.body:
Fixes the Javascript Exporter to work with the latest Emscripten SDK + Latest Codebase.

1) Removed the Usage of .a and .o files (archive and object files that were used by default) This is done to fix the unresolved symbols errors which cause the export to fail.
2) Added a Hack in rg_etc1.cpp file to handle weird behavior on javascript side which is causing "<" operation to give wrong results.

Wiki for getting H5 export working.
https://github.com/vkbsb/godot/wiki/export_html5

data.title: current editor default theme is too dark and not constrasted ennough
data.body:
Hi,

I don't know how it is for other Godot users, but at long, current theme is becoming very painful for my eyes when I'm working in a room with natural lighting from windows.

I think current theme is more adapted to work in dark rooms.

Would it be possible to :
- make a slightly better contrasted theme that would be more adapted for both illuminated and dark rooms ?
- or add an option to switch between several themes ?
- or apply a pixel-shader script that would allow users to tweak theme contrast and hue in real time ?

data.title: Fix for KinematicBody2D::move
data.body:
The current implementation of KinematicBody2D::move() has some problems. See an example here https://drive.google.com/open?id=0BwT-rSmeee4IT3Q3WmR4aTQ3Skk&authuser=0 . In the example, the square moves down vertically; however, when it reaches the slope it seems to slowly slide until it falls from it.

The cause of the issue seems to be the following. There are three points where collision detection is used in KinematicBody2D::move(): 1) recover for current collision, 2) the actual movement and 3) the calculation of the remaining move vector. For 1) and 3), the margin attribute of the body is used as a parameter of the collision detection; however, for 2) it is not, and zero is used instead. This causes the body to approach other objects beyond its margin, and therefore the collision recovery in the next call forces the object to move away from the colliding object, causing, in the example, the "sliding" effect.

If the margin attribute is passed as argument for the collision detection in the movement part, the given example works as expected (the square does not slide).

That said, I don't know the exact purpose of the margin attribute altogether, and I don't know either if there is a reason for using 0 as margin in the movement part. The comment at the beginning of the method body is rather discouraging with respect to doing changes lightly. Please share your thoughts on it and let me know if the fix is actually not valid.

data.title: Update file_access_windows.cpp for mingw cross-compile
data.body: Cross compiling on linux failed on this file. Changing case of the windows.h and shlwapi.h allows mingw to find these headers but setting WINVER 0x0500 is needed for the compiler to find ReplaceFileW

data.title: Export target for Ubuntu Mobile / Jolla SailfishOS?
data.body:
Both are similar new mobile platforms using qt/qml and are quite close to standard gnu/Linux.

For Ubuntu Touch see here: https://developer.ubuntu.com/en/start/

HTML5 would probably work as on FirefoxOS, but native binaries would be awesome.

data.title: Theroa Build error corrected
Import .dae requires the target path to exist
data.body: When importing a .dae, if you pass a non-existent path into Target path and click import, you get just "Error importing scene"(BTW, why are there 2 buttons on that window "Accept" and "Cancel"....). It will be better to either display a more descriptive message, or attempt to create the path beforehand.

data.title: Cutout-Animation wiki page displays incorrect image for the section "Batch Setting Transition Curves"
data.body:
The image displayed here:
https://github.com/okamstudio/godot/wiki/Cutout-Animation#batch-setting-transition-curves

is the same image displayed in the section right above it:
https://github.com/okamstudio/godot/wiki/Cutout-Animation#moving-sprites-above-and-behind-others

I believe the image in the Batch Setting Transition Curves was mixed up.

data.title: [Fix] make_dir_recursive on Windows
data.body: function normally tries to create c: which isn't possible, because the access is denied, handling ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED as ERR_ALREADY_EXISTS lets the function skip the creation of c: .

data.title: No sound in GNU/Linux distributions that use *just* ALSA
data.body:
I opened one of my projects to check something, and I noticed that the game background music wasn't audible anymore. When I had Pulseaudio, the music and sound were played without problem, but now that I get rid of it, I cannot hear anything.

I compiled Godot from the source code hosted here in Github two days ago.

data.title: 3DArea gravity point is related to absolute (0,0,0) point
data.body:
When creating area with it's own gravity, and checking 'Gravity Point', the origin of gravity is always set to absolute 0,0,0 point. 
Here is minimal sample project illustrating this bug: 
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/168251/godot/some/issues/gravity_point.7z
